   IN ATLANTA: Paul Foutch at 404 526-5456

   IN WASHINGTON: Elliott Jaspin at 703 551-1033 or (cell phone)
703 725-7031

   NATIONAL

   SHOOT-MAIN _ ATLANTA _ Latest developments in the aftermath of
the Thursday slaying of nine people in two Atlanta ofice buildings.
(Atlanta Journal-Constitution).

   WITH

   SHOOT-PROFILE _ ATLANTA _ Exeperts say Mark Barton fits an
increasingly common profile: An angry, depressed, middle-age man
looking for retributiuon on the way to killing himself. (Williams
Atlanta Journal-Constitution).

   SHOOT-BULL _ ATLANTA _ How the shootings rank in terns of other
national carnage. (Manuel, Atlanta Journal-Constitution).

   CAJUNS _ ABBEVILLE, La. _ In case you thought all Cajuns lived
in south Louisiana, you were wrong. Cajuns are the descendants of
the French who were expelled to Louisiana from Canada in the 18th
century, but in the centuries since they've been flung to the four
corners. But rural Louisiana is still the spiritual heart of Cajun
country, with its funny form of French, its music and food and
laissez les bon temps roulez approach to life. And beginning this
weekend (JULY 31), as many as half a million Cajuns from around the
world will gather here for the second-ever World Acadian Congress.
The first one was in Canada four years ago. We visit Abbeville, the
most Cajun spot on earth and talk to organizers of the Hebert
family reunion, which will take place Aug. 5-7. Included in their
program is a French mass, a street dance, and the cooking of a
5,000-egg omelet. Yes, this is somehow very traditional.
(Konigsmark, Atlanta Journal-Constitution). 25. MOVED.

   POLITICS

   GORE-WOMEN _ WASHINGTON - The hiring of Celinda Lake is the
strongest signal yet that Vice President Al Gore recognizes the
importance of women to his White House hopes. In an interview, Lake
talks about the campaign ahead and her career advising politicians
to not ignore women voters. (Shepard, Cox News Service).

   MOVED Friday in (w) Washington and (p) politics categories.

   BUSH-EDUCATION _ AUSTIN _ (Fourth in an occasional series.) As
Gov. George W. Bush begins to educate Americans on who he is and
what he would do as president, education will be on the top of the
list. Texas is being touted as a shining example of improvement, no
small feat in the country's second largest state, which used to
rank near the bottom in most academic indicators. Bush has made
education a top priority, from ending social promotion to
increasing accountability and testing to increasing state funding
of public schools. But he's been unable to deliver on vouchers, and
some critics say he cannot take credit for the recent rise. The
seeds of Texas' success were sown in the mid-1980s, with laws to
create smaller classes, give more money to poor school districts
and increase academic standards. (Brooks, Austin
American-Statesman). 53. WITH PHOTOS, GRAPHICS, LOGO.

   INTERNATIONAL

   CLINTON-BALKANS _ SARAJEVO, Bosnia and Herzogovina _ A look at
what Clinton's Balkans experience says about the U.S. role in the
world at the close of the American Century, and a glimpse at the
uncertain way forward in the Balkans, where thousands of U.S.
troops are likely to be posted well into the next century. (Deans,
Cox News Service). 40. MOVED Friday.

   BRITAIN-MAYOR _ LONDON _ A story advancing the goodwill visit of
Peter Levene, Lord Mayor of London, to Atlanta, Miami, Charlotte,
N.C. and San Francisco next week. Although he will have no specific
agenda, he will meet with various government and business leaders
-- including Georgia Gov. Roy Barnes and NationsBank Chairman Hugh
McColl. He believes the Southeast is a very important market for
London's finance and insurance industries. He also has had a house
on Sea Island for 14 years and considers Georgia a second home of
sorts. (Roughton, Cox News Service). 20. WITH PHOTOS (mugs
available). MOVED Wednesday.

   VIRGIN-TRASH _ ST. THOMAS, Virgin Islands _ Here's one picture
you won't see on any postcard: trash, and mounds of it. The U.S.
Environmental Protection Agency estimates that the Virgin Islands
produce 9.2 pounds of garbage per person per day, more than double
the U.S. mainland average. One reason is all the tourists who
visit, many making day trips from cruise ships. But the problem is
that the only landfill, Bovoni, can no longer absorb all the
garbage, and there's no money to clean up the mess. Why? Because
apparently the Virgin Islands is nearly broke. As a result of
hurricane damage, declining tourism revenue and mismanagement, the
Virgin Islands is saddled with a $1.2 billion debt, a stupefying
sum for a population of just over 100,000. (Emling, Cox News
Service). 20. WITH PHOTO. MOVED Wednesday.

   ISRAEL-BEDOUIN _ UM BATEEN, Israel _ The Bedouin in the Abu Kaf
family raise camels and goats, grow their own food and value the
self-sufficiency they have on their desert hillside. ``We are
satisfied with our lives. We just want to stay on our land,'' said
52-year-old Talal Abu Kaf, seated on carpets on the land where his
family has lived for hundreds of years. About 3,500 Bedouin live in
here in Um Bateen, but as far as the Israeli government is
concerned, Um Bateen barely exists. The village is one of about 45
Bedouin settlements in the Negev Desert that remains unrecognized
by the government and therefore denied its own local government or
services such as electricity. (Kaplow, Cox News Service). 25. WITH
PHOTOS and LOCATOR MAP INFORMATION. MOVED Wednesday.

   WASHINGTON

   WOMEN-COMPUTERS _ WASHINGTON _ Put a computer in the home, and
women are nearly as likely as men to go on line. But millions of
women, despite their surging Internet savvy, won't buy a computer
unless a man helps choose it, buy it and set it up. The reasons
most women balk at buying computers are complicated, but the
consequences are clear, both for ``have-not'' families and for
society as a whole. (Geewax, Cox News Service).

   With WOMEN-DATA _ Chart material.

   Moved Monday in (w) Washington, (l) lifestyle and (f) financial
categories.

   With photos.

   COXNET FOCUS PAGE

   EDs: This is the CoxNet Focus page for the week. The page will
be available Friday by 1 p.m. EDT.

   COXNET FOCUS 0731 WOMEN AND COMPUTERS _ Put a computer in the
home, and women are nearly as likely as men to go on line. But
despite their surging Internet savvy, millions of women won't buy a
computer unless a man helps choose it, buy it and set it up. The
reasons most women balk at buying computers are complicated
(Geewax, Cox Washington Bureau). Art includes 3-column color photo
of woman's hand holding a mouse, an 18-pica color photo of Apple's
iMac computer.

   WITH

   NEW TECHNOLOGIES _ Experts say new technologies may soon make it
easier to use computers. (Geewax, Cox Washington Bureau) Art
includes 1-column color illustration of a computer and a 3-column
color photo of woman shopping for a computer.

   INFO BOX _ Data on women and computer use.

   GORE-WOMEN _ WASHINGTON - The hiring of Celinda Lake is the
strongest signal yet that Vice President Al Gore recognizes the
importance of women to his White House hopes. In an interview, Lake
talks about the campaign ahead and her career advising politicians
to not ignore women voters. (Shepard, Cox News Service).

   MOVED Friday in (w) Washington and (p) politics categories.

   STONEWALK _ PARKSBURG, Pa. _ Mounted on a wheeled caisson, the
Memorial Stone to Unknown Civilians Killed in War is being pulled
from Massachusetts to Arlington National Cemetery by a peace group
that hopes to have it installed there. The volunteers talk about
their quest. (Hill, Cox News Service). WITH PHOTOS. MOVED Thursday.

   GEEWAX-Y2K-COLUMN _ WASHINGTON _ For millions of Americans,
nothing fosters a sense of security quite like a fat roll of crisp
$20 bills. Polls show that as more people begin preparing for New
Year's Day and the computer problems that may come with it, the
desire to hoard cash is growing. The Federal Reserve Bank is
bracing for large cash withdrawals late in the year, even while
assuring customers that such stockpiling is unnecessary. (Geewax,
Cox News Service). 22.
